steps.title: Find a GP clinic near you
steps.text: Search online or ask local NGOs / neighbors which GP practices accept new patients.

steps.title: Fill out a registration form
steps.text: Most clinics have a paper form or online form. Staff can help if your language is different.

steps.title: Bring documents
steps.text: Usually an ID or passport and proof of address (like a letter, bill, or asylum papers).

steps.title: Confirmation
steps.text: The clinic will confirm and send you a letter or card once you are registered.

checklist: Proof of address (rental contract, bill, asylum letter)
Previous medical info (if you have it)
Interpreter or support person if language is a barrier

whatToBring.warningNote: ⚠️ If you don't have documents, you can still try to register. Ask the GP clinic or NGOs for help.

roles.title: First point of contact
roles.text: GPs are usually your first stop for health problems. They listen and decide what to do next.

roles.title: Prescriptions
roles.text: They can give prescriptions for medicine you need.

roles.title: Basic checks
roles.text: They do blood pressure, blood tests, or simple examinations.

roles.title: Referrals
roles.text: If you need a specialist, they write you a referral.

roles.title: Family care
roles.text: They care for both adults and children, often the whole family.

start.title: Do you have a very high fever (over 39°C)?

injury.title: Do you have a serious injury or heavy bleeding?

chronic.title: Do you have ongoing symptoms (cough, pain, skin issues)?

gp.title: You should see a GP.
gp.subtitle: They can examine you and refer you if needed.

emergency.title: This is an emergency.
emergency.subtitle: Call 112 immediately or go to the nearest hospital.

self.title: Self-care may be enough.
self.subtitle: Rest, drink water, try paracetamol for fever or pain.

sections.heading: Book an Appointment
sections.text: Most GP practices require you to book an appointment in advance. Some also have online booking.

sections.heading: Walk-in Clinics
sections.text: If you cannot reach your GP, you can visit a walk-in clinic for urgent but not life-threatening issues.

sections.heading: Bring Important Documents
sections.text: Take your health card, ID, and any medical records or medication you are using.
